Comment: It is unfortunate that the disgusting behaviour of more than just a handful of senators tends to be what comes foremost to our thinking of the Senate. If one sets aside the disgusting behaviours that dominate our discussion of the upper chamber, and considers the intended role of the Senate, and those times when it has indeed fulfilled its expectations, it is clear that it has--or should have--a real benefit for democracy. More than once, in the US, Britain and Canada, better legislation has resulted from the review and amendments from the second chamber in the respective governments. But how we can cleanse it to function soberly and effectively is indeed a difficult question.

Comment: Don't disagree with your point - however I think it important to distinguish between true pipeline companies and midstream companies.  KEY is a midstream company.  Midstream companies as the name implies look after a myriad of services between the wellhead and the pipeline that takes the product downstream to market.  As such are more tied to the day to day and cyclical nature of the petroleum business than the major pipelines.    So the business risk level between the two is different.

Comment: brindy
"Maybe we should limit DB pensions to some standard reflecting what those in the private sector have available to them"
Th e private sector has the increased interest rate caused by inflation. In other words, the interest rate available to the pension fund is approx the real rate plus the inflation rate. That is reflected in the return on investment. The higher inflation, the higher the return on investment. In the late 70s and early 80s, when inflation averaged 9%, interest went as high as 18%. Now it would be considerably lower.

In the 70s and 8os, federal actuaries assumed real interest of about 3%, inflation 3 1/2%.

The problem with Anchorage's "highway" system is that the highways out of town were built north and south of town starting in the 1970's without any connecting "highway" style roads within much of the "bowl". This facilitated tremendous growth  in Eagle River, Chugiak, Birchwood, Rabbit Creek neighborhoods, etc. but then the resultant traffic pretty much stops when it comes to midtown or downtown. From there a lot of it is distributed onto city streets that are not designed to take the traffic.  Anchorage residents have to pay more tax dollars as we pass road bonds to fix the city streets. These neighborhoods are impacted as well.

Comment: I find this new movement of trying to label oneself very interesting. When I was young, I looked almost exactly the same as Nicholas, very androgynous, but I was female.  I was so upset when anyone tried to label me (calling me a dyke, fag, queer, tom-boy, etc.). I wanted to avoid labels; I was a woman, and being a woman can mean a lot of different things. Now everyone is straining to come up with as many new labels as there are people. It's kind of sad, really, because I feel like it is trying to separate us rather than unite us. We are all human, we are all born on a continuum of male/female; your clothes, hair, makeup, mannerisms, etc. do not make you male or female. Your DNA, hormones, gene expression, is unique for each person, but it doesn't make each person a new species. A man with long hair and makeup is not a woman, a woman with short hair and jeans is not a man. They are what they are, and that should be OK. It should be enough. I would prefer just one label, "human."

Comment: Catch quota remains unchanged under the monument expansion, and it is being caught in record time. Last year an entire years worth of fish quota was filled by mid-July. Rather than stopping, additional quota was purchased from American Samoa and CNMI so that fishing can continue here in Hawaiian waters. This is potentially dangerous, because those quotas should be regionally fished. 

In regards to fish availability, catch numbers are up, so why are we still importing fish? Why are our locally caught fish exported instead of going to feed people locally? The local caught fish should stay in Hawaii to feed local people. Frozen carbon monoxide treated fish was imported prior to the expansion, and only 5% of the total longline effort even comes from the expanded area.  We should keep protections in place for Papahanaumokuakea.

Comment: Some people are pet lovers; other people are indifferent to pets or even pet haters.

I am a dog guy myself. Since I live alone I truly cherish the companionship my grand old dog provides me. We have had many years together.

I don't mollycoddle her but I do take her for annual exams with a vet and I will have any other health issues dealt with that might need a vet's expertise. She runs free on my farm to her heart's content and occasionally there can be mishaps needing a vet visit......e.g. porcupine quills. I feed her mostly what I eat. Burgers on the BBQ?.......ground beef for the dog. Steak on the BBQ?.......bones and scraps for the dog, perhaps even her own steak. For some reason my old dog has acquired a taste for carrots and she will dig them from the garden if I can't stop her. Not a big deal really, I just plant lots of carrots each year.

I have no idea what I spend on my dog annually and I won't beat up Financial Facelift subjects for spending money on pets either.

Comment: Technically a catechism,"to teach orally", is the summary or exposition of doctrine used in catechesis rather than a printed document. That has been the case since the Apostles, who had catechumens (those undergoing catechesis) who wished to become Christians.

Since documents were handwritten and not all were literate, these were often in the form of simple texts that could be memorized along the lines of the Apostles‚Äô Creed.

When printing became available, small books of instruction appeared. The use of a question and answer format was popularized by Martin Luther in his 1529 Small Catechism.

While called a catechism, the Catechism of the Council of Trent published in 1566 was not for the laity but a reference book for priests and bishops. Trent was NOT the first Council where doctrines were defined.

Anti-discrimination laws don't list all the reasons someone could be refused service, they define classes of persons upon which refusal of service cannot be based. As long as the refusal is not based on a class, and it's applied equally to all people, it is legal.

I agree that BLM and the Forest Service were not primarily created to protect wildlife habitat. And yet, without the large acreages set aside for national forests and grasslands and even larger areas managed by the BLM, there would be very little public land available for wildlife, hunting, and wildlife watching in the West. Here's a puzzle for you. Why does the Forest Service manage national grasslands when they have no forests to cut? Watershed and wildlife conservation would be my guess. All of the agencies included in the estimate of public expenses take wildlife management and habitat protection seriously, even if it isn't their main function. And even if you dropped ALL of the wildlife-related work done by the BLM and USFS, the amount of funding provided by nonhunters would still overshadow that by hunters. Stop defending Sen. Kelly. He's not listening to either of us.

Comment: I have often found that those who produce articles like this seldom read the paper into which their words placed.  Rasmusson (sic) Foundation did a tax (income, fuel, alcohol) and PFD restructuring, after their roadshow sales job for these efforts, on the impacts of the Governor's plan they were promoting.  Their findings were that All of the Above hit the low-income families the hardest.

A sales tax would also be applied to the 2,000,000 tourists who visit our state every year. Sales taxes can be structured so that they are seasonal, or scaleable, or exempt certain types of purchases.  So, a sales tax from April through September of 5% wherever no sales taxes exist, and 2% where sales taxes exist, and exempting food and pharmaceuticals, would still raise more than any income tax.

Restructuring and/or capping the dividend fund is the most harmful thing the legislature can do. Consensus among those I trust is:  Cutting the budget and use ER and CBD to cover until rebound is best.

Comment: I really enjoyed read this article. I believe bears and other wildlife can peacefully co-exist with humans in the wild if humans have a respect for the wildlife. Part of that means giving the wildlife a wide berth, areas where they can freely and safely live without human interference. Educating humans on giving/allowing wildlife to be themselves (wild). Having a healthy respect for wildlife, remembering that you are in their "home" and practicing good manners  as a guest. 
I live in a "semi-rural" area where black bears pass through my property (yard) daily. There are at least two if not more dens located in the forest behind my house. I have a salmon spawning creek running through my property, along side my house.  Bears often fish and climb up my trees to eat their catch. Mama bears leave their cubs in trees outside my windows while they go down to the beach to fish. 
Eagles spend the entire year in the area along with many other critters.
I keep my property "wild" for them.

Comment: This article is shallow and very subjective. It is misleading to insinuate that Indians at large enjoyed "privilege" during apartheid. The majority of Indians that came to S.A 150 years ago were mainly indentured labourers (not merchants) and are not currently well off, but rather working class. Hard work, discipline, respect, education, perseverance, emphasis on family & a feeling of non-entitlement has been the corner stone of the Indian diaspora success, not just in S.A.
After Apartheid many impediments were removed and Indians have now been able to realise their potential collectively. It is important to acknowledge our history, but the future of greater importance. Nation building across all cultures in important. Race, gender, religion, caste - have been used to divide people for centuries. Lets not fall into that trap. A conservative and narrow minded person could influence future generations. Lets preach tolerance, forgiveness, understanding and open-mindedness instead...

Comment: Some relevant background regarding "self-determination": The taxpayers of Canada will this year alone give the government of Nunavut $42,055.00 for each of its residents (source at link below). They comprise what the federal government calls the "major transfers":  "Canada Health Transfer",  "Canada Social Transfer" and "Territorial Formula Financing".  By comparison, the highest per capita payment to a province is to PEI ($3,981.00 this year).   Put another way, the government of Nunavut receives over 10 times the per capita annual funding from federal taxpayers than any province.

Comment: To discuss the BC Government's property transfer tax revenue as a focal point for debate about the residential real estate bubble in our urban centres is a classic example of focussing on an incidental, secondary byproduct in the midst of a crisis.

Surely, if there is to be even a slim possibility that BC is to avoid both the twin dangers of runaway asset inflation (soon followed by crisis and multi-double-digit correction) in land prices (on the one hand) or such a correction now (on the other), then the pace of turnover and price increase needed to slow without panic setting in.  

Such a slowing entails a slowing both of growth in this Government tax revenue and of the growth of paper profits of current homeowners but so be it. These are the least of the problems that the BC Liberal Government has allowed to grow out of control relating to residential housing prices and the social and economic problems they create and threaten for our future.

Comment: Getting a good education comes from good values. Actually caring about your own education and a love of learning. If children are raised in families that do not care, or show they care, then that attitude reflects down to the children. It's an attitude of society. My oldest went to public school in Oregon k-4 and loved school and got excellent grades. We moved here and his attitude changed, his grades fell and he hated school. The children around him had terrible attitudes about school and it rubbed off. We homeschooled 7-12 and his whole attitude changed again. Now I homeschool the rest of my kids with no more than 3 hours of school a day and they love school and are far above grade level. I can't change society but I can raise kids who love to learn.

Comment: Agreed.  I'm colour blind and as such, my fellow citizens are demanding that all traffic lights get changed out to symbols instead.

We'll also need all lane markings on the roadway to be colour-neutral.  

I'll require all emergency lighting and signage in all public places to be changed out to a colour-neutral system.

We'll need consumer product legislation that requires all lights, dials and indicators on equipment to be changed out to colour-neutral symbols please.

This world of colour is highly discriminatory and offensive to us.  In fact, we need to pass M-104, which bans the term "colour blind", to a more progressive term of "colour capable". 

This issue affects approx. 5000 Canadians out of a population of 35 million.  It should only take $5 to 10 billion to force all provinces and municipalities to comply with our needs.

It's called reasonable accommodation.  And I believe this demand is reasonable as my charter rights are being violated.

Comment: As a veteran with more than 35 years on active duty, I believe there should be a point when we stop searching for military personnel missing from past wars.  World War II ended 72 years ago.  If remains are found and identified, it is becoming increasingly difficult or impossible to find a close living relative to accept them.  Moreover, what are called remains often times are bone fragments no larger than a fingernail which are placed in full-size caskets for transportation to relatives and burial.  The Defense POW/MIA Accounting Agency met its quota in 2017 by the disinterment of the USS Oklahoma‚Äôs 388 casualties from Pearl Harbor buried as ‚Äúunknowns‚Äù at Punchbowl. Comment: Must be election season. Anyway, last time the train discussion came up, it was pointed out that for a modest $1.5 billion, Via rail could provide dedicated passenger tracks in the Montreal-Ottawa-Toronto corridor. (Parts of the corridor are currently shared with freight, leading to delays, less frequent service, slower speeds, and frustration). For $4 billion the whole corridor could be electrified.

Ontario is now talking about spending 4x to 10x that amount serving a handful of much smaller cities in Southern Ontario. Is it *really* necessary to build an entirely new rail line to reduce the Toronto-London travel time from 2 hours to 1 hour? Presumably there are similar improvements that could be made to existing train routes for a fraction of the cost.

But I can already tell that the province wants those photo-ops with hard hats and shovels. Enhancing existing stuff is not as attractive as building new stuff. So high-speed rail it is.

Flattening electricity demand
Many participants, including BC Hydro,
recognize that, since the recession, demand
has not returned to what it was and evidence
indicates that total demand is not growing
in most places in North America ‚Äì in most
cases it is flat or declining. The Panel finds BC
Hydro‚Äôs expected compound growth rate for
the residential, commercial and light industrial
sectors to be significantly higher than the flat
or declining growth rates forecast in other
North American jurisdictions. In the Panel‚Äôs
view, a likely explanation for this is the result
of lower demand-side management (DSM)

example, BC Hydro has not implemented
time-of-use and other load curtailment
measures that have been broadly adopted

Comment: What is regret? It is an emotional state where we tend to put the blame on ourselves for a bad result. It involves a sense of sadness where we wish we could undo a previous event or wish we hadn‚Äôt done it that way. But, apart from being a hurtful emotion, for people who are young, it could act as a beneficial emotion. This painful emotion can impel us to take corrective measures in order to rectify our mistakes which were committed in the past or could create a mindset of taking up a new path. However, we must also understand, the lesser the chances a person gets to rectify a mistake, the more pain it suffers from which has a drastic impact on his mental and physical well being. But, the main question we need an answer to is ‚ÄòHow to deal with regret?‚Äô

Comment: So if the issue is that Cottage Grove is using "low cost, off the shelf" lead testing strips, wouldn't it have been a good idea to include some reason to believe that the testing strips in question don't... you know... work? Comment: Pay is a function of power.  It has little to do with inherent value of the CEO or the wage earner.  Let me ask a question.  If say a 1000 CEO's disappeared tomorrow, what would be the effect on our nation?   Will there not be 10-100 men or women of competence to replace each CEO?  The human capital of a large organization can number in the 10's of thousands- is upper management really worth what we pay?   

I respect leadership including business.  But how much is too much compensation?  Is one human life valued in billions of dollars of wealth worth relegating thousands to deep poverty when we can't fund our social foundations like heath, shelter, food, education?

I don't know about CEO tax specifically, but I would like to live in a nation that values all lives, regardless of personal wealth.  I don't expect economic equalty at all, but the nation has a serious distorted sense of privilege empowered by wealth not morality/ethics.   I show leadership respect in ways beyond pay.

Comment: My thoughts on a number of good points made here:
1)  Will anything come of this conference?  Ans:  the point of the conference is to inform and engage, not to make decisions.  Without information and engagement, good decisions are less likely to be forthcoming.  These conferences are building blocks on which a (hopefully!) good planning structure can be created.  Topics need to be visited and revisited before an optimal consensus can emerge.
2)  Trust.  It is in short supply nationally and locally.  Too often we look for evil intentions on the part of others instead of looking for common ground that can be expanded.
3)  Population growth.  We can promote it willy-nilly (which seems to happen during periods of economic stagnation), rail against it (which seems to happen when it is too fast), or thoughtfully plan for it.  Our islands would look and feel quite different -- better, I would argue -- if 50 years ago we had planned for a state population of nearly 1.5 million.

Comment: I commend your success. It shows it can be done. 
But I ask you, do you believe that since you did it anyone can?  I don't know your profession, but there are some professions that require a degree. Certainly you would not want a pilot, doctor, teacher, veterinarian, professor, officer, administrator, accountant, or other such job holders to take care of you without a degree. We had a guy stay here who had a two year radiology degree with about $20,000 in debt. Hired originally for $50 an  hour,  then told he was an independent part time contracted employee at $23 an hour.
As you may know,  your experience is called anecdotal.  A survey of one. Yes, others have done well without a college degree and there is an effort to focus more on trades. But even trades now often require running a computer. 
So way to go! You are successful. It can be done. But certainly you don't believe that applies to most people who need a college degree and who now are $50,000 in debt when they start work.

Comment: First off, a true proportional system is nothing but a myth. The system that the NDP and Greens forward will not be a true pro-rep system. It will be a mixed system just like FPTP. That's a 100% guarantee. 

However, their mixed system will:
a) result in perpetual minority governments 
b) gives rise to fringe lunatic parties
c) paralyse decision making

There is no PERFECT voting system and FPTP has served Canada very well despite the rhetoric otherwise. The real problem with FPTP is that parties who solely serve ideological masters (NDP, Greens) can never win an election.  If the Greens and NDP ever came up with a more moderate platform that represents a wider range of the population, instead pandering solely to their ideological base, they could actually win an election once in a while.

Comment: You are incorrectly assuming that "treaties" can only occur between nation states. Comment: My father retired after 30 years as a Boeing engineer.  He saw the production of the B-29s and the development of the 707.  In those days, Boeing was a proud American company.  It was also almost completely unionized, and as a result its workers were well-paid.  Several of the fathers in our neighborhood were machinists at Boeing.  There was no difference in the standard of living of their families and ours.

In the 1970s, Boeing underwent a severe crisis; like many other defense contractors it was hit hard by the end of the Vietnam War.  It downscaled drastically, and then slowly rebuilt itself as a global corporation.  By the 1980s, Boeing was breaking its unions by telling them, "OK, you don't like that, we'll just build it overseas."  And I hear from a current Boeing employee that a preponderance of floor workers are foreign (mostly Asian) and don't even speak English well enough to take directions from a supervisor who can't speak their language.  Bye bye, Miss American Pie.

But without specifics of how Alaska (and the Nation) can do better, criticism is shallow and useless.

Comment: Yeah, that kind of thing is why the climate benefit of getting rid of cows is nonsense.  If the cows don't eat the grass, it eventually rots in the wet season producing amounts of methane and CO2 similar to what the cows produce.  But if one were to actually do a serious study on what happens in reservoirs, especially in somewhat arid areas, the methane produced by decay will be relatively little compared to the net suppressed carbon emission that equivalent fossil fuel plants would produce.  Yes, the fossil fuel plants would tend to produce CO2 while some rot channels produce methane.  Folks like to say methane is bad.  But here is the rub.  The half life of methane in the atmosphere is about a decade.  The half life of CO2 in the atmosphere is centuries.  The integrated effect of CO2 over its incredible lifetime makes simple comparisons of relative IR absorption strengths between the two gases incomplete to say the least.

Comment: I support reducing the income spread, but not at the cost of tax fairness. 
Recently, I sold an income property, achieving  a $400,000 capital gain. I have to record $200,000 in one taxation year and face a serious bump up in my tax rate.
The reality is that this √≠ncome was earned over the twenty year period in which I managed the property. Some of the profit was simply due to inflation and not real profit at all. I will nevertheless be taxed on this so called profit. Some of the profit is the result of sweat equity, the labour I put towards maintenance and improvements in each of the twenty years I managed the property (and served my tenants) . Nevertheless, the government will tax me as if I earned this income in a single year, all the better to increase its slice of the pie.
Yes, I have money. Yes, I am a target. The government unfairly uses me to reduce the income spread I worked so hard to achieve. Packing the results of twenty years of labour  into one taxation year is not fair.

Comment: I got a Mossberg .410 bolt action shotgun for Xmas when I was 10 years old and a 12 gauge Wingmaster when I was 13. I have owned guns my whole life and was once a member of the NRA (until they became an advocate for the gun industry instead of the sportsman).
The NRA gun safety courses I attended as a teenager in the 1950s taught us to never, ever carry a loaded gun around in public. The NRA instructor told us that it was not only irresponsible but also dangerous. Heck, the only people who owned a handgun in those days were law enforcement, security guards, and people who enjoyed a visit to the firing range and/or engaged in competitive shooting. Personally, I knew of no one in our community who owned a handgun.
There was no such thing as a concealed carry permit back then because we all knew how dangerous and just plain stupid it would be to carry a gun around in public, loaded or unloaded. When did that change ... and WHY?

Best,

RTD

Comment: "According to NOAA, most of the U.S. state temperature records still stand from prior to the 1960's.How can that be ?"

There are two kinds of temperature records:

1) Peak daytime instantaneous temperatures - these are more likely to be set during drought times, when humidity is low, and the sun builds heat during the day, which is later radiated away at night, it's the 1930s for USA when a widespread drought hit that country (and why new records are being set mainly in those states hit by a newer drought).

2) Average temperatures - this is overall warmth, day and night combined, over some time period and geographical space, often global for a year, and this is how climate change manifests itself (since this phenomenon is not caused by the sun), it's what melts ice,  and this is happening in recent times for the USA, and for nearly everyone else too.

Comment: "...shut it down and die."

Most Catholics don't even know what the Curia is, much less know who is in that institution or group; but you want it dismantled. Maybe replace it with global representatives from the 150 or so National Conferences of Bishops representing 1.2 billion Catholics? I don't know. I haven't the answer except that it will take a long time to dismantle the Curia -- to make the unrigging successful. Bishops can do it by asserting themselves as individual national bodies, but that seems unlikely right now. Some National Conferences of Bishops, of course, are more progressive than others. In the meantime, in dealing with abuse in churches (and everywhere, really), the best route (for bringing about reform) seems to be through local civil courts, sympathetic laypeople and clerics, the press, and Pope Francis. If courts jailed a few bishops, that might help a lot, too.

Comment: CHILDREN LEARN WHAT THEY LIVE
Dorothy Law Nolte 
If a child lives with criticism, he learns to condemn. 
If a child lives with hostility, he learns to fight. 
If a child lives with fear, he learns to be apprehensive. 
If a child lives with pity, he learns to feel sorry for himself. 
If a child lives with ridicule, he learns to be shy. 
If a child lives with jealousy, he learns what envy is. 
If a child lives with shame, he learns to feel guilty. 
If a child lives with encouragement, he learns to be confident. 
If a child lives with tolerance, he learns to be patient. 
If a child lives with praise, he learns to be appreciative. 
If a child lives with acceptance, he learns to love. 	
If a child lives with approval, he learns to like himself. 
If a child lives with recognition, he learns that it is good to have a goal. 
If a child lives with sharing, he learns about generosity.

(2) after getting past one or two intersections a driver hits a Red Light at the 3rd intersection

Comment: James, I was posing the question that people often ask. If mountain biking is more dangerous, then why aren't more bikers harmed than hikers? The obvious rebuttal is that if there are many more times the number of hikers than bikers, then even if biking is more dangerous there could still be fewer injured bikers than hikers. And yet the odds of being injured by a bear would be higher for bikers than hikers. As I attempted to point out, there are no national or statewide figures for numbers of people who hike or bike in bear country, so comparisons are difficult, although in one instance reported by Herrero in Banff, it was evident that bikers were more at risk. Your "logic-fail" is you forgot to account for numbers of users.

Comment: Schnurr writes that CPI-common: ‚Äúwhich the central bank says is the best gauge of the economy‚Äôs underperformance, held at 1.3 per cent‚Äù. The Bank of Canada has shown a preference for CPI-common as its core inflation measure over the other two measures that now make up its operational guide, more it would seem, because for a long time it showed lower inflation rates than any other measure than due to any inherent advantages. However a core inflation measure is not equivalent to a gauge of the economy‚Äôs underperformance, and even the Bank of Canada never suggested it was. In fact its technical box on ‚ÄúNew measures of core inflation‚Äù claims that the new core measures are to be preferred to CPIX because of an alleged stronger ‚Äúpeak correlation between the output gap at time t and the core inflation measure x quarters later [t + x],‚Äù where x is between two and seven.

Comment: I have fished the Copper since 1968. In those days we fished a 48 hr and a 36 hour period every week. Now if we fish two periods a week it is two 12 hour openers. We also fished nearly to the grass banks.  Now we are forced to risk out lives outside to try to make a living. One boat flipped and the skipper was pulled out of the water. The skipper of another boat ended up in the water and died this last opener. He was a long time friend of mine from back when I started in this fishery. Before the inside was totally closed to us, we were only allowed to fish one opener per week to let extra kings up the river. Then the biologist decided on his own to take even more inside days away from us. Don't tell me that we haven't shared in conservation. You don't know what you are talking about.

My first home mortgage required more than 50% of my net income. It was, a times, at  struggle and it was a tiny, tiny property. Buying a first home has never been real easy. Nor should it.

While Rob and others argue that things are different this time. I am not so sure.

Young people should not be encouraged to give up on the idea of home ownership even though it may seem very difficult through today's lense.

Comment: Ooooh, thank you refurbish bike volunteers!  If I had an extra pile of money, I'd be delivering a truck load of bikes to children whose households can't afford a bike.  I know exactly how these children feel; left outs.  An age appropriate bike can make all the difference in a child's life.

I remember growing up, me and my sisters use to  go around our neighborhood and ask to borrow neighbors bikes for a few hours.  One time we were so desperate to borrow three bikes and one of the bikes only had one peddle, but that didn't stop us.  We each took turns trading off and riding the bike that had only one peddle.  Borrowing bikes from neighbors was the good old days when neighbors knew how to be neighbors.

Kudos to the volunteers and thank you for letting me reflect on a childhood memory.

Comment: The organizations that own SAT, ACT and WorkKeys are large, private, for-profit corporations.  Requiring all Alaska students to take these particular tests transferred Alaska public funds to Lower 49 big business pockets.  

Alaska needs some sort of standardized testing for progress monitoring, but it's high time we settled on something simple, practical, consistent and inexpensive rather than constantly chasing after various schemes.  The old HSGQE/SBA wasn't terrible, but the way it was implemented was rough on kids with learning disabilities or recent immigrants, many of whom would do fine in the workplace or higher ed and had the actual skills the tests were supposed to measure, but struggled with the high-stakes bubble test format.  I'd like to see a shorter test focused on concrete math and English skills - arithmetic, reading comprehension, etc. ( no artsy abstract subjective questions) - and if it's used as a graduation exam, the opportunity to show a portfolio instead.

Comment: Possibly.
All the air crews knew is that their missions were bombing runs with one unique bomb each. They had trained to make an extreme turn after dropping the bomb (to avoid the air shock) and were given a vague description of what the bomb would do, but that was it.
Although the crews of "Enola Gay" and "Bockscar" had trained for several months in the US, and then over Japan with so-called "pumpkin bombs" (bombs with the same shape and aerodynamics, but with a conventional explosive payload, as the implosion atomic bomb dropped on Nagasaki), I believe both air crews had flown conventional bombing runs over either Germany or Japan. They were experienced crews.
If the air crews were "conflicted", it would have been after the atomic bombs exploded and after the air crews became fully aware of the enormous damage and loss of life caused by the bombs.

Comment: The "20-year hiatus" did not exist. When you use the hottest year on record (the 1998 El Nino) as your starting point, the subsuquent decades of warming will not look like much. Comment: I'd love to see a study of Catholic parish closings.

The study would look at the "vitality" of parishioners' interior lives!

To get at this dimension, we could use reasonable proxies: Compare "closing parishes" with "non-closing parishes", using the following metrics...

- Number of daily Masses
- Earliest starting time of the first daily Mass (if it's after 8:30, that parish is in danger of needing to be closed). 
- Hours a week that Confession is offered.
- How many days of the week other than Saturday is Confession offered.
- How many Marty Haugen songs are sung each week? (negative indicator)
- How frequently is Confession mentioned in homilies, in a positive sense.
- Is the sanctuary open all day long allowing people to visit Our Lord.
- How frequently is the Sanctuary used to pray the Holy Rosary as a community?

Comment: An ecological awareness is more than recycle bins and canvas shopping bags. I've heard the issues but not so much about actionable responses, especially on global concerns such as this.  So, I found this... available on Amazon Audible.

"In The Blue Sapphire of the Mind, Douglas E. Christie proposes a distinctively contemplative approach to ecological thought and practice that can help restore our sense of the earth as a sacred place. Christie argues that, at the most basic level, it is the quality of our attention to the natural world that must change if we are to learn how to live in a sustainable relationship with other living organisms and with one another. He notes that in this uniquely challenging historical moment, there is a deep and pervasive hunger for a less fragmented and more integrated way of apprehending and inhabiting the living world - and for a way of responding to the ecological crisis that expresses our deepest moral and spiritual values."

A Contemplative ecology!

Comment: Rochdale68, how much does a teacher in your private school make? And is it a fair wage?

He lost a month's pay and parents a half year's tuition while the public system had to pick up the pieces.

I hope your kids are at a good private school. Some don't deliver what they promise. Some are havens for troubled rich kids. 

Of course, some parents move their children to the Catholic School system because they think it's more rigorous. I'm not sure of that. And some people pay more for a house in a good school district.

Comment: What difference is there between challenging the prosecution's  case at a preliminary inquiry or at a trial?  None.  The prosecution leads its evidence and the defence is allowed to cross-examine and challenge it.  In neither case is the accused required to lead any evidence.

If the prosecution's case is specious and lacks merit (i.e. has failed to prove an essential element of the offence), that will be obvious when it has completed entering its case and the defence can bring a no evidence motion which, if accepted by the court, will result in a directed verdict of acquittal.

So what's the problem?

Comment: Yes, lots of spin.  Haven't we already seen this from the media and the RE industry with regard to Vancouver prices after the tepid B.C. "foreign buyers' tax"?  The bottom line in the GTA and a swath of southern and central Ontario is that housing prices are still up from last year, which were way up from 2015, which were way up from 2014.  Lots of fancy graphs accentuate the drop in home sales and rate of price increases over the past two months, but can't hide the fact that the prices are still "up" and completely out of whack with local incomes:  the "average" house/dwelling in Toronto costing almost 12 times the median family income.  It's an economic disaster for locals and fundamentally diminishes the liveability of their communities.  Federal and provincial governments, get your act together:  track the money in RE; seriously discourage foreign capital investments in RE.   Demand Canadian income tax be paid on all money used, by whomever, to purchase housing or property.

Comment: Algebra is not racist. However, we should still get rid of college algebra.

As a professional mathematician with nine years teaching experience at the college level and 20 years experience in industry, I firmly believe that algebra is a high school class. Colleges and Universities should not accept anyone who hasn't already had it. Operations research, statistics, and modeling should be taught in university, not remedial courses.

If anyone lacks a background adequate to get into a four-year institution, they may take remedial classes at a community college and then transfer.

High schools should teach geometry, trigonometry (including spherical trigonometry), and algebra. "College algebra" should not exist.

Comment: Thomas Square is one of the few public parks that allows dogs. I used to bring my dog there all the time. Unfortunately, in the past few years homeless dwellers and trash left behind by park users has caused me to frequent the park less. With all the buildings in the city, existing or in the building phase, Honolulu officials need to assure that its residents have nice outdoor public spaces like the owners of the new condos in Kakaako have (but their grassy areas are/will be private). NYC can manage to keep public parks so I'm sure Honolulu can figure it out too. 

Additionally, Admiral Thomas' memory was honored with that park because he protected the Hawaiian Monarchy. In 1843 Lord George Paulet of the British Royal Navy demanded that King Kamehameha III cede to the British crown. Five months later Paulet's commanding officer, Admiral Richard Thomas, arrived in Honolulu, apologized for Palet's actions, and restored Hawaiian sovereignty on July 31, 1843.

Comment: The Glob,

Yes, Canada can "afford" to support multiple air frames. We can also afford to buy every Canadian a doughnut made of pure gold. That being said, it is far more expensive to support and maintain a fleet with 2 (3 with the legacy F-18s) air frames. So, if we were to do so, the added expense would need to be justified. Australia's decision to convert "their Super Hornets into Growlers as a complement to the F-35" makes their decision to support two air frames more reasonable, but that doesn't mean that Canada would benefit to the same degree from a similar venture or that we should follow suit.  Canada's principle fighter requirements are to defend Canadian and NORAD airspace jointly with the US and for use in force projection UN/NATO sanctioned engagements abroad. As a member of NATO (Australia is not a member) and NORAD, we don't need Growlers as the US has them and already supports our fleet in virtually every engagement we are in. The expense isn't justifiable in the least

False!

Boston, says, "An effort was made at first to secure an old armory near the boat landing, as that was in touch with a base on board ship, but it was refused, as was the opera house, the only two places of suitable dimensions available. Captain Wiltse drove up, and said he had secured a temporary place in a hall to the rear of the opera house, commonly known as Arion Hall.

Comment: I think there's gotta be a middle ground here. The traffic problem on the North Shore won't be solved by taking away the food trucks (because honestly, there's no place like the North Shore), and the littering problem is not caused by all tourists. I've seen lots of locals/businesses/developers disrespect the land much worse. The best thing about the food trucks is that it gives the area some soul and personality. It's not the typical fast food joint, it's not a big corporate gig, and it's far from town. It's small business, it's artistic, gives people a chance to live their dreams and also an job/income creator. Find a way to provide proper amenities, permits and parking, as I'd like to see more soul and less ego drive the economy. Also, make recycling a priority at all beach parks with composting bins included with information board. You can't stop the people from coming, especially since the state advertises and relies so heavily on tourism.

Comment: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2004_United_States_election_voting_controversies
2004 United States election voting controversies
During the 2004 United States presidential election, concerns were raised about various aspects of the voting process, including whether voting had been made accessible to all those entitled to vote, whether ineligible voters were registered, whether voters were registered multiple times, and whether the votes cast had been correctly counted. More controversial was the charge that these issues might have affected the reported outcome of the presidential election, in which the incumbent, Republican President George W. Bush, defeated the Democratic challenger, Senator John Kerry. Despite the existing controversies, Kerry conceded the election the following day on November 3.
The final recount also reversed the outcome of this election. But Kerry had already conceded.

Comment: The Chiefs seem to be under the delusion that Canada is some kind of "United Nations" arrangement of sovereign states.  Sorry, but it is not.  

These so-called nations are not sovereign and have no more right to "self-determination" than provinces or cities.  This stunt is little more than a thinly-disguised attempt to establish a de facto sovereignty association arrangement.   Sorry, no sale.

If the feds and provinces want to get together to talk business, good on them.  If they want to invite mayors to discuss issues of particular interest to cities, great.  But that doesn't mean the mayors should stay for the whole meeting as if they were some kind of city-state.  If they want to invite Indigenous organizations to discuss issues of particular interest to them, that's great too.  But that doesn't mean they should stay for the whole meeting either.

Comment: Not really.
Wikipedia, "war powers act"
"The War Powers Resolution (also known as the War Powers Resolution of 1973 or the War Powers Act) (50 U.S.C. 1541‚Äì1548) is a federal law intended to check the president's power to commit the United States to an armed conflict without the consent of the U.S. Congress."

It only allows "that the U.S. President can send U.S. Armed Forces into action abroad only by declaration of war by Congress, "statutory authorization," or in case of "a national emergency created by attack upon the United States."

First strike is therefore prohibited (but has been violated by probably every President since at least Regan).  Mattis seems to be indicating there is no limit to the President's power and only "perhaps" Congress has say.

Comment: An appeal court will not review findings of fact unless they are "unreasonable"; it is not enough that the appeal judges would have come to a different conclusion, they must find that the trial judge's finding of fact was COMPLETELY unsupported by the evidence. It is very rare for an appeal court to make such a ruling; consequently, it is very rare for an appeal court to interfere with a trial judge's findings of fact. Ordinarily, an appeal is a review for error of law only.

Comment: If you think putting Alaska Natives in charge of ANY natural resource will provide any degree of protection or conservation, you apparently do not read much. Check out the history of the Kilbuck caribou herd. Or, if you really want an education, go to Bethel in May and June when the Kuskokwim delta is filled with ducks and geese tending their nests. You can watch fifteen or twenty boats go out there every morning and spend the day killing ducks and geese even though it is totally illegal and unethical, until their boats are literally full, then coming back to town, taking a dozen or two home for supper, coming back the next day, dumping the other hundred or so dead birds out of the boat and going back out to blast a couple hundred more. Yep, they are definitely "Stewards of the Land" alright. Or go do a census of game within 30 miles of ANY village in NW or SW Alaska. No moose, no caribou. If it moves, kill it. If it flies it dies.

Comment: "Kansas Crowd Applauds Cardinal Burke's Stump Speech"
Operational definition of "stump": the dying remnants of a dismembered tree, the productive part of which has already been utilized. Small stumps can usually be ignored as they deteriorate rapidly and are replaced by viable vegetation. Large stumps constitute an impediment to both natural growth and useful cultivation and continue to absorb otherwise useful nutrients in a futile pretense of vitality. In isolation, the latter can be left to eventual self-deterioration as a habitat or refuge for rodents, fungi, etc. However for productive utilization of the "terroir" the impediment must be forcibly removed.

Comment: And the very last line of the article tells us that our health care costs the most of those in the study.  So we have OK outcomes but at a huge cost.  From my years in disability management I saw employees refuse to follow health care providers direction in relation to life style related conditions because we have an enabling system that rewards (or fixes) chronic conditions during acute phases.  I have seen people literally eating themselves to disability--like blowing their retinas, kidneys and ugly foot ulcers due to out of control type II diabetes--a condition which is sometimes reversible if patient follows doctors orders.  Our system is clogged with these folks--dialysis units have increased 300% over the last decade..  And dialysis patients are getting progressively younger.  The local dialysis unit goes to overtime everyday (but that's another story) Yet those of us who look after ourselves are caught in the queue when we need help.

Comment: Note that "direct" and "nonstop" flights are not the same thing, though it's an extremely common misconception. A nonstop flight is exactly what it sounds like ‚Äî it goes from origin to destination without stopping. A direct flight, however, makes at least one stop along the way, but doesn't require the passenger to change planes. (The other type of flight is a connecting flight, which does require a plane change.) Despite the headline used here, it sounds like a *nonstop* flight is being described.

Comment: Aircraft flying over land use VHF radio waves to communicate with air traffic control. Pilots change frequency often because the transmitters only cover roughly 60 miles in any direction. The reason for this limited coverage distance is that VHF is line of site propagation, therefore the radio signal cannot follow the curvature of the earth. 

In order to stay in contact with air traffic control when flying over areas that don't allow for VHF transmitter placement (like oceans), Aircraft us HF radio. This is because HF radio is skywave propagation, it refracts off the ionosphere to provide over the horizon communication. 

If the earth where flat, the only transmitter limitation would be the power of the transmitter. If you ever go out in the country and see an extremely tall radio tower, you are looking at proof the earth is round.

There are so many obvious proofs that we live on a "spinning ball" that if one cannot find any, one is purposely ignoring it.

Comment: As electricity consumption continues to fall throughout North America, energy surpluses are becoming a greater problem. Ontario typically exports around 15 TWh of electricity at low (or negative) prices each year and is curtailing further TWh of available power.  We could easily fuel most of the light vehicles in the Province with surplus electricity at minimal cost. In addition, it takes relatively small amounts of solar to power an EV.  For example, our 10 kW rooftop solar system has produced around 100,000 kWh over the seven years since it was installed, while our driving 140,000 electrically powered km has only used around 30,000 kWh. EVs are so efficient that they will not pose a serious problem to the power grid and can help to stabilize the grid by providing dispatchable power demand (and potentiality dispatchable power supply).
